entry.title: Whiteboards
entry.content: When a presentation finishes, there are always those who want to know more, or discuss issues with the speaker. It is human nature to leave your seat in the audience, approach the speaker’s chair and exchange further comment after the talk itself is over. And this is not an activity we would want to suppress. So we have set up four whiteboards and other equipment in a 50m2 space at the heart of the exhibition. Speakers will be invited to take up position here after their presentation and respond to all those clamouring for more information, or who have something special to communicate.

entry.title: Expo
entry.content:
The expo area at Oslo Spektrum

The exhibition space at JavaZone is a central meeting place for partners and attendees. All of the conference partners will be here. During the conference, this area becomes a real melting pot of activities, with events organised by the individual partners and centrally by JavaZone. There will be a variety of competitions with great prizes to be won. There will be talks and discussions linked to the presentations, along with more social events.

Relax/gamezone

The exhibition space is also where we give in to our natural human frailties. There are limits to what the body can tolerate, over the course of two days, in our quest for knowledge. So at JavaZone, between the action, we let you abandon yourself to old vices! Relax/gamezone is our take on the watering hole, a chance to reenergise yourself playing computer games. Here you will find hammocks and beanbags, Nintendos, Playstations, X-boxes and worse besides!

entry.title: ClubZone
entry.content:
ClubZone is JavaZone’s legendary party. With more than 2,000 attendees, there is an obvious need for meeting places outside the conference and exhibition spaces as well as in, a need that JavaZone accommodates with a variety of social events. Along with individual partners, JavaZone is sponsoring entertainment and refreshment at four different venues in Oslo city centre during the conference. We call this ClubZone and we think it will offer something for every taste.

Queens Pub & Pianobar

Showing the Norway-Macedonia match and serving drinks from the brewery.

Dattera til Hagen

A stand-up festival and drinks from the brewery.
See Dattera til Hagen’s website

Gloria Flames

Concert with the Valentourettes and drinks from the brewery. See Gloria Flames’ website

Cafe con Bar

DJ and drinks from the brewery. See Cafe con Bar’s website

entry.title: About JavaZone
entry.content:
On these pages you will find information about everything to do with JavaZone. There are answers to everything: what JavaZone is, how to book a hotel room, meeting places and events during the conference, how to get to know other attendees, and how you can make a contribution as part of the crew. You can also read previous years’ websites and get an idea of the JavaZone atmosphere. JavaZone is more than just a conference. It’s a place to meet, network and socialise!

What is JavaZone

JavaZone is Scandinavia’s biggest meeting place for software developers, and one of Europe’s most important. JavaZone has been described as a high-quality, independent conference, and is a forum for knowledge exchange, recruitment and branding. Some 40 large and mid-sized businesses – our partners – exhibit their products and services in a separate exhibition space, while more than 90 presentations are given in the conference facilities. Each year, around 2,300 conference tickets are sold. This means that, over the two days the conference lasts, we deliver more than 200,000 hours of expertise. When you add to this the many informal discussions that take place at stands and between attendees, JavaZone stands out as a tremendous arena for knowledge transfer. Of course, a conference involving so many developers is also a key arena for recruitment. Through their exhibitions and other activities, the large and mid-sized companies use the opportunity to promote their business and recruit new staff.

One of the key factors in the huge success of JavaZone has been the support of great numbers of volunteers. It is safe to say that this is a conference by and for software developers. Each year, thousands of hours are put into making the conference as successful as possible. The technical programme is carefully structured and planned and the programme committee invites speakers from all over the world. Professionals know what professionals want, so the speakers are hand-picked, and the presentations are highly relevant. In the tradition of the conference, speakers are not paid an appearance fee for their contributions. Around half of the presentations are given in English and the other half in one of the Scandinavian languages. The conference’s unconventional and non-commercial approach has also boosted its popularity.
